abstract.p: Garden for Cultural Services of French Embassy in Manhattan is being created by architect Stan Allen and landscape architect James Corner; photo (Currents column) (S)

block.p: Coming next summer, a garden on Fifth Avenue near 78th Street that will be modern yet verdant, and will glow at night. Stan Allen, a Manhattan architect, and James Corner, a landscape architect in Philadelphia, won the French Embassy competition to design the garden next to the Cultural Services of the French Embassy. The winner: honey locust trees, a steel grate parquet floor and translucent fabric lanterns, all lighted from beneath. ''It's an urban garden with an artificial surface, because the floor is a counterpoint to the neo-Classical walls, and because there's no competing with Central Park,'' Mr. Allen said. The $150,000 garden will be used for embassy parties but will not be open to the public.

The winner: honey locust trees, a steel grate parquet floor and translucent fabric lanterns, all lighted from beneath. The $150,000 garden will be used for embassy parties but will not be open to the public.
